connection_notes: Follows Star Wars Legends: Rebellion Omnibus Vol. 2. The Shadows of the Empire storyline is essential Legends reading. Infinities stories are non-canon "what if" tales worth exploring.

title: Star Wars Modern Era Epic Collection: Yoda's Secret War
synopsis: Jason Aaron's Star Wars run continues with issues #15-30 and Annuals #1-2, delivering major storylines including "Yoda's Secret War" and "The Scourging of Shu-Torun." Issue #15 reveals Yoda's clandestine mission during the Clone Wars, while the Shu-Torun arc (#16-19) sees Vader crush rebellion on a vital Imperial mining world. Annual #1 explores C-3PO's red arm from The Force Awakens, and issues #26-30 begin "The Screaming Citadel" crossover with Doctor Aphra. This volume solidifies Aaron's flagship Star Wars title as essential modern canon.
connection_notes: Continues from Star Wars Modern Era Epic Collection: Skywalker Strikes. "Screaming Citadel" (#26-30) crosses with Doctor Aphra. Leads to Star Wars Modern Era Epic Collection: Rebel Jail.

title: Star Wars: Visions Treasury Edition
issues_collected: Star Wars: Visions #1; Star Wars: Visions - Peach Momoko #1; Star Wars: Visions - Takeshi Okazaki #1; and material from Star Wars: Darth Vader - Black, White & Red #1
synopsis: This treasury edition presents Star Wars: Visions #1, Visions - Peach Momoko #1, and Visions - Takeshi Okazaki #1 in oversized format, celebrating the anime anthology series with manga-style storytelling. Peach Momoko's distinctive artistic vision reimagines Star Wars mythology through a Japanese lens, while Okazaki delivers his own anime-inspired tale. The collection showcases how international artists interpret the Star Wars universe outside traditional continuity.
connection_notes: Standalone anthology inspired by the Disney+ Star Wars: Visions series. Non-canon stories that don't connect to Marvel's main Star Wars continuity.

title: Star Wars: Kanan Modern Era Epic Collection: The Last Padawan
issues_collected: Kanan - The Last Padawan (2015) #1-5 and Kanan (2015) #6-12
synopsis: Kanan Jarrus's complete comic saga unfolds across issues #1-12, exploring how Padawan Caleb Dume survived Order 66 and became the cynical cowboy Jedi of Star Wars Rebels. The Last Padawan arc (#1-5) depicts his master Depa Billaba's sacrifice and Caleb's desperate escape, while issues #6-12 follow his fugitive years and eventual transformation into Kanan. Greg Weisman and Pepe Larraz deliver essential backstory for one of Rebels' most compelling characters, making this required reading for fans of the animated series.
connection_notes: Essential reading for Star Wars Rebels fans. Set during and after Order 66, bridging Revenge of the Sith with the Rebels animated series. No direct sequel collections.

title: Star Wars: Legacy Of Vader - The Reign Of Kylo Ren Vol. 1
issues_collected: Star Wars: The Legacy of Vader #1-6
synopsis: The Legacy of Vader #1-6 explores Kylo Ren's transformation from Ben Solo, chronicling his fall to the dark side and the rise of the First Order. This miniseries fills gaps between The Last Jedi and The Rise of Skywalker, examining how Vader's legacy haunted and shaped his grandson. While providing additional context for the Sequel Trilogy, it's supplemental character exploration rather than essential storytelling.
connection_notes: Set during the Sequel Trilogy era. Supplements The Rise of Kylo Ren miniseries and films, but not required reading for understanding Kylo's arc.

title: Star Wars: The High Republic - Fear Of The Jedi
synopsis: Unable to provide accurate synopsis without issue information. This trade paperback appears to be part of Marvel's High Republic publishing initiative, set 200 years before the Skywalker Saga during the Jedi Order's golden age. The High Republic comics explore the Jedi at their height and the mysterious threat of the Nihil marauders. Recommend verifying collected issues before reading.
connection_notes: Part of the multimedia High Republic initiative. Reading order varies; check Marvel's High Republic reading guide for proper placement among novels and other comics.

title: Star Wars: The Rise Of Skywalker Adaptation
issues_collected: Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker Adaptation #1-5
synopsis: Marvel's official comic adaptation of the final Skywalker saga film, condensing J.J. Abrams' Episode IX into five issues. Writer Jody Houser translates the film's major beats—Rey's final confrontation with Palpatine, the reveal of her lineage, and Ben Solo's redemption—into sequential art. Like most film adaptations, this offers little beyond what's on screen, serving primarily as a visual companion piece for collectors.
connection_notes: Follows: Star Wars: The Last Jedi Adaptation. Part of Marvel's modern film adaptation series. For completists wanting the entire sequel trilogy in comic form.

title: Star Wars Legends: The Old Republic Omnibus Vol. 2
issues_collected: Star Wars: The Old Republic (2010) #1-6; Star Wars: The Old Republic - The Lost Suns (2011) #1-5; Star Wars: Lost Tribe of the Sith - Spiral (2012) #1-5; Star Wars: Knight Errant (2010) #1-5; Star Wars: Knight Errant - Deluge (2011) #1-5; Star Wars: Knight Errant - Escape (2012) #1-5; Star Wars: Jedi vs. Sith (2001) #1-6; and material from Star Wars Tales (1999) #16-17 and #24 and Star Wars Visionaries (2005)
synopsis: This massive omnibus explores the ancient Star Wars galaxy thousands of years before the films. Star Wars: The Old Republic #1-6 and The Lost Suns #1-5 tie into the BioWare video game, while Knight Errant #1-5, Deluge #1-5, and Escape #1-5 follow lone Jedi Kerra Holt battling Sith warlords during the New Sith Wars era. The centerpiece is Jedi vs. Sith #1-6, chronicling the climactic Battle of Ruusan that ended the Sith as an army. Essential reading for fans of Legends continuity and Old Republic lore.
connection_notes: Follows: Star Wars Legends: The Old Republic Omnibus Vol. 1. These stories explore eras rarely covered in Star Wars comics, connecting to Knights of the Old Republic tales and the ancient Jedi/Sith conflict.

title: Star Wars Legends: The Old Republic Omnibus Vol. 2 Joe Quinones Cover
issues_collected: Star Wars: The Old Republic (2010) #1-6; Star Wars: The Old Republic - The Lost Suns (2011) #1-5; Star Wars: Lost Tribe of the Sith - Spiral (2012) #1-5; Star Wars: Knight Errant (2010) #1-5; Star Wars: Knight Errant - Deluge (2011) #1-5; Star Wars: Knight Errant - Escape (2012) #1-5; Star Wars: Jedi vs. Sith (2001) #1-6; and material from Star Wars Tales (1999) #16-17 and #24 and Star Wars Visionaries (2005)
synopsis: This massive omnibus explores the ancient Star Wars galaxy thousands of years before the films. Star Wars: The Old Republic #1-6 and The Lost Suns #1-5 tie into the BioWare video game, while Knight Errant #1-5, Deluge #1-5, and Escape #1-5 follow lone Jedi Kerra Holt battling Sith warlords during the New Sith Wars era. The centerpiece is Jedi vs. Sith #1-6, chronicling the climactic Battle of Ruusan that ended the Sith as an army. Essential reading for fans of Legends continuity and Old Republic lore.
connection_notes: Variant cover edition. Follows: Star Wars Legends: The Old Republic Omnibus Vol. 1. These stories explore eras rarely covered in Star Wars comics, connecting to Knights of the Old Republic tales and the ancient Jedi/Sith conflict.

title: Star Wars: Jedi Knights Vol. 1 - Guardians Of The Republic
issues_collected: Star Wars: Jedi Knights (2025) #1-5
synopsis: A new 2025 series set during the High Republic era, following the Jedi Order at its zenith as guardians of peace and justice. Jedi Knights #1-5 launches fresh storylines exploring the Republic's golden age, when Jedi were legendary heroes rather than the hunted remnants of the Empire era. Early to assess long-term significance, but part of Marvel's expanding High Republic initiative alongside novels and other comics.
connection_notes: Part of the interconnected High Republic publishing initiative. Connects to: Star Wars: The High Republic series. For readers invested in this era of galactic history.

title: Star Wars: Darth Vader Modern Era Epic Collection: Vader Down
synopsis: This Epic Collection would center on the landmark 'Vader Down' crossover between the Star Wars and Darth Vader ongoing series, where Vader's TIE Fighter crashes on a Rebel-controlled planet, forcing him to fight his way through squadrons alone. The event showcases Vader at his most terrifying and unstoppable, cementing his status as the galaxy's greatest threat. A defining moment in Marvel's modern Star Wars publishing that demonstrates why Vader remains iconic.
connection_notes: Crossover between Star Wars (2015) and Darth Vader (2015) series. Essential reading for fans of Marvel's modern Vader portrayal. Connects to ongoing storylines in both series during this era.

title: Star Wars: Doctor Aphra - Friends And Enemies Omnibus
issues_collected: Star Wars: Doctor Aphra (2020) #26-40; Star Wars: Revelations (2023) #1 (Doctor Aphra story); and Star Wars: Sana Starros (2023) #1-5
synopsis: The rogue archaeologist's saga concludes in this omnibus collecting Doctor Aphra (2020) #26-40, where Alyssa Wong's run explores Aphra's complex relationships with both enemies and allies. The collection includes the Sana Starros miniseries #1-5, spotlighting Aphra's smuggler ex-girlfriend, plus relevant material from Star Wars: Revelations #1. These issues wrestle with Aphra's perpetual struggle between self-preservation and doing the right thing, while expanding the criminal underworld of the Star Wars galaxy.
connection_notes: Concludes the 2020 Doctor Aphra series. Follows: earlier Doctor Aphra collections. Character originated in Kieron Gillen's Darth Vader run. Essential for fans of morally complex Star Wars characters.

title: Star Wars: Doctor Aphra - Friends And Enemies Omnibus Betsy Cola Cover
issues_collected: Star Wars: Doctor Aphra (2020) #26-40; Star Wars: Revelations (2023) #1 (Doctor Aphra story); and Star Wars: Sana Starros (2023) #1-5
synopsis: The rogue archaeologist's saga concludes in this omnibus collecting Doctor Aphra (2020) #26-40, where Alyssa Wong's run explores Aphra's complex relationships with both enemies and allies. The collection includes the Sana Starros miniseries #1-5, spotlighting Aphra's smuggler ex-girlfriend, plus relevant material from Star Wars: Revelations #1. These issues wrestle with Aphra's perpetual struggle between self-preservation and doing the right thing, while expanding the criminal underworld of the Star Wars galaxy.
connection_notes: Variant cover edition. Concludes the 2020 Doctor Aphra series. Follows: earlier Doctor Aphra collections. Character originated in Kieron Gillen's Darth Vader run. Essential for fans of morally complex Star Wars characters.

title: Star Wars: Darth Maul - Black, White & Red
issues_collected: Star Wars: Darth Maul - Black, White & Red #1-4
synopsis: An anthology miniseries presenting Darth Maul stories in stark black, white, and red artwork across four issues. The limited color palette emphasizes the Sith apprentice's brutal nature and iconic crimson lightsaber. Like Marvel's other Black, White & Red anthologies, this features short stories from various creative teams exploring different facets of Maul's character—his training under Sidious, his hatred of the Jedi, and his relentless pursuit of revenge.
connection_notes: Part of Marvel's Black, White & Red anthology series. Standalone stories that complement but don't require knowledge of ongoing Star Wars continuity. For Maul enthusiasts and fans of stylized art.

title: Savage Sword Conan Orig Marvel Yrs Omnibus HC Vol. 03 (MR)
issues_collected: SAVAGE SWORD OF CONAN (1974) 29-44 AND MARVEL COMICS SUPER SPECIAL (1977) 9
synopsis: Marvel's black-and-white Savage Sword magazine continues with issues #29-44 plus Marvel Comics Super Special #9. This volume features Roy Thomas and John Buscema's mature-readers Conan tales, delivering the sword-and-sorcery violence and dark fantasy that the Comics Code wouldn't permit. These issues showcase some of Buscema's finest work, adapting Robert E. Howard stories and original adventures with the gritty, atmospheric tone that made Savage Sword legendary among 1970s comic magazines.
connection_notes: Follows: Savage Sword of Conan Omnibus Vol. 2. Runs concurrent with: Conan the Barbarian color series. Essential for fans of Marvel's Conan era and John Buscema's artwork.

title: Conan Barbarian Orig Marvel Yrs Omnibus HC Vol. 04
issues_collected: CONAN THE BARBARIAN (1970) 84-115, ANNUAL (1973) 4-5 & WHAT IF? (1977) 13
synopsis: Roy Thomas and John Buscema's definitive Conan run continues with issues #84-115, plus Annuals #4-5 and the classic What If? #13 ('What If Conan Walked the Earth Today?'). This volume includes major storylines adapting Robert E. Howard's original tales and Marvel's own mythology-building adventures. The Buscema era represents the artistic and narrative peak of Marvel's Conan series, balancing savage action with sophisticated storytelling that transcended typical barbarian fare of the 1970s.
connection_notes: Follows: Conan the Barbarian Omnibus Vol. 3. Runs concurrent with: Savage Sword of Conan. This volume continues the heart of the Thomas/Buscema collaboration that defined Marvel's Hyborian Age.

title: Marvel Art Of Savage Sword Of Conan (MR)
synopsis: An art-focused collection showcasing the stunning black-and-white illustrations from Marvel's Savage Sword of Conan magazine. This oversized presentation highlights the work of legendary artists who brought Robert E. Howard's Hyborian Age to life in stark, dramatic fashion. More of a gallery showcase than a narrative collection, celebrating the visual legacy of Marvel's mature-readers Conan series.
connection_notes: Companion piece to Savage Sword of Conan Omnibus series. Best appreciated after reading some Savage Sword stories to understand the context of the artwork.

title: Conan The Barbarian By Kurt Busiek Omnibus HC
issues_collected: CONAN: THE LEGEND (2003) 0; CONAN (2004) 1-28, 32, 39, 45-46; CONAN: BOOK OF THOTH (2006) 1-4
synopsis: Kurt Busiek revitalizes Conan for Dark Horse in this acclaimed run from Conan #1-28, plus key issues through #46. Busiek faithfully adapts Robert E. Howard's original stories while expanding the barbarian's world with fresh adventures. Features the "Born on the Battlefield" origin and masterful collaborations with artists Cary Nord and Greg Ruth. Book of Thoth #1-4 adds supernatural horror to the Hyborian Age.
connection_notes: The definitive modern Conan run and ideal starting point for new readers. Leads to: subsequent Dark Horse Conan series. Predates Marvel's 2019 relaunch.

title: Savage Sword Conan Orig Marvel Yrs Omnibus HC Vol. 04
issues_collected: SAVAGE SWORD OF CONAN (1974) 45-60
synopsis: The legendary black-and-white Savage Sword magazine continues with issues #45-60, featuring mature-readers adventures by Roy Thomas, Michael Fleisher, and other top writers. These issues showcase John Buscema, Alfredo Alcala, and Ernie Chan delivering some of their finest Conan artwork. The magazine format allowed for more violent, adult-oriented storytelling than the Comics Code-approved color comic.
connection_notes: Continues from: Savage Sword Omnibus Vol. 3. Leads to: Savage Sword Omnibus Vol. 5. Essential reading for fans of mature-readers Conan and classic Marvel black-and-white magazines.

title: Conan Chronicles Epic Collection: The Song Of Belit TPB
issues_collected: CONAN THE BARBARIAN (2012) #7-25
synopsis: Brian Wood's acclaimed Dark Horse run continues with Conan the Barbarian #7-25, spotlighting the legendary romance between Conan and pirate queen Bêlit. This arc adapts and expands Howard's classic "Queen of the Black Coast," tracking their relationship across dangerous seas and supernatural threats. Wood balances action with character development, making this a standout emotional journey in Conan's life.
connection_notes: Continues from: Conan Chronicles Epic Collection Vol. 1. The Bêlit saga is one of Conan's most important relationships. Leads to: later Dark Horse Conan material.

title: Conan The Barbarian By Aaron & Asrar HC
issues_collected: CONAN THE BARBARIAN (2019) #1-12
synopsis: Jason Aaron and Mahmud Asrar launch Marvel's 2019 Conan revival with issues #1-12, returning the barbarian to the House of Ideas. Aaron crafts a narrative spanning Conan's entire life, from young thief to aging king, while exploring his complex relationship with dark sorcery. The run features bold visual storytelling but received mixed reception compared to previous definitive Conan work.
connection_notes: Marvel's modern Conan relaunch after decades at Dark Horse. Can be read independently of previous continuity. Concurrent with: Savage Sword of Conan (2019) series.

title: Conan The Barbarian: The Original Marvel Years Epic 2 Hawks From The Sea
issues_collected: Conan the Barbarian (1970) 14-26
synopsis: Roy Thomas and Barry Windsor-Smith continue their groundbreaking run with Conan the Barbarian #14-26, featuring the iconic "Hawks from the Sea" storyline. These issues see Windsor-Smith's art reach new heights of sophistication while Thomas deepens the Hyborian Age mythology. Includes memorable encounters with supernatural threats and the development of Conan from wandering youth to hardened warrior.
connection_notes: Continues from: Conan Epic Collection Vol. 1. Leads to: Epic Collection "The Curse of the Golden Skull." Part of the essential Thomas/Windsor-Smith run that defined Marvel's Conan.

title: Savage Sword Of Conan: The Original Marvel Years Omnibus Vol. 5 HC Asrar Cover
issues_collected: SAVAGE SWORD OF CONAN (1974) 61-72
synopsis: The mature-readers Savage Sword magazine continues with issues #61-72, delivering more black-and-white Conan adventures. Roy Thomas, Michael Fleisher, and Don Glut provide scripts while John Buscema and Ernie Chan illustrate brutal battles and dark sorcery. These issues maintain the magazine's reputation for sophisticated storytelling beyond the constraints of mainstream comics.
connection_notes: Continues from: Savage Sword Omnibus Vol. 4. Parallel reading to the color Conan the Barbarian series but with mature content. Features some of Buscema's finest Conan artwork.

title: Savage Sword Of Conan: The Original Marvel Years Omnibus Vol. 5 HC Mattingly Cover
issues_collected: SAVAGE SWORD OF CONAN (1974) 61-72
synopsis: The mature-readers Savage Sword magazine continues with issues #61-72, delivering more black-and-white Conan adventures. Roy Thomas, Michael Fleisher, and Don Glut provide scripts while John Buscema and Ernie Chan illustrate brutal battles and dark sorcery. These issues maintain the magazine's reputation for sophisticated storytelling beyond the constraints of mainstream comics.
connection_notes: Continues from: Savage Sword Omnibus Vol. 4. Parallel reading to the color Conan the Barbarian series but with mature content. Features some of Buscema's finest Conan artwork.

title: Conan The Barbarian Epic Collection The Curse Of The Golden Skull
issues_collected: Conan the Barbarian (1970) 27-42, Material from Annual (1973) 1
synopsis: Roy Thomas continues his definitive run with Conan the Barbarian #27-42 and Annual #1, featuring the multi-part "Curse of the Golden Skull" saga. John Buscema takes over full art duties, establishing the visual template for Marvel's Conan. These issues deepen the Hyborian Age with recurring characters like Red Sonja and showcase Thomas's mastery of Robert E. Howard's sword-and-sorcery world.
connection_notes: Continues from: Epic Collection "Hawks from the Sea." Essential Thomas/Buscema collaboration. The foundation for decades of Marvel Conan storytelling.

title: Conan The Barbarian: The Original Marvel Years Omnibus Vol. 6 HC Buscema Cover
issues_collected: CONAN THE BARBARIAN (1970) #150-171, CONAN ANNUAL #8-9 and WHAT IF? (1977) #43
synopsis: The original Marvel series concludes its remarkable run with Conan the Barbarian #150-171, featuring the climactic "Book of Skelos" storyline. These final issues see King Conan facing threats to his throne while writers James Owsley and Michael Higgins guide the barbarian toward his ultimate fate. Annual #8-9 add standalone adventures, while What If? #43 explores an alternate timeline for Conan.
connection_notes: Continues from: Conan Omnibus Vol. 5. The conclusion of Marvel's original 1970-1993 series. Essential for completionists wanting the full Thomas-era Conan saga.

title: Conan The Barbarian: The Original Marvel Years Omnibus Vol. 6 HC Siqueira Cover
issues_collected: CONAN THE BARBARIAN (1970) #150-171, CONAN ANNUAL #8-9 and WHAT IF? (1977) #43
synopsis: The final stretch of Roy Thomas's legendary Conan run, spanning Conan the Barbarian #150-171 and Annuals #8-9. These issues continue Conan's adventures across the Hyborian Age, featuring stories by Thomas, Alan Zelenetz, and Michael Fleisher with art from John Buscema and others. The volume includes What If? #43's alternate Conan tale. This era marks the transition period before the title's creative team changes, closing out an important chapter of Marvel's Conan saga.
connection_notes: Continues from: Conan Omnibus Vol. 5. Final volume of the Roy Thomas era. Concurrent with King Conan (1980) series for Conan's later years.

title: Conan The Barbarian Epic Collection: The Original Marvel Years - Queen Of The Black Coast TPB
issues_collected: CONAN THE BARBARIAN (1970) #43-59 and material from SAVAGE SWORD OF CONAN (1974) #1
synopsis: Roy Thomas and Barry Windsor-Smith adapt Robert E. Howard's beloved novella "Queen of the Black Coast" in Conan the Barbarian #58-59, one of the most celebrated Conan stories ever published. Issues #43-59 chronicle Conan's romance with the pirate queen Bêlit and their adventures on the high seas. The collection includes material from Savage Sword of Conan #1, bridging the color comics and black-and-white magazine lines. Windsor-Smith's art reaches its pinnacle in this volume.
connection_notes: Part of the Roy Thomas/Barry Windsor-Smith Bronze Age run. Essential for Bêlit's introduction, a key figure in Conan lore. Leads to: Epic Collection - Of Once And Future Kings.

title: Conan Epic Collection Shadows Over Kush
issues_collected: Conan the Avengers (2014) 1-19
synopsis: Collects the complete 2014-2015 Dark Horse series Conan the Avenger #1-19 by Fred Van Lente and various artists. This run continues Dark Horse's chronological approach to Conan's life, featuring self-contained adventures set during the barbarian's mercenary years. The series maintains the pulp adventure tone while exploring different corners of the Hyborian Age. Note: This is Dark Horse material, not "Original Marvel Years" despite the Epic Collection branding.
connection_notes: Part of Dark Horse's modern Conan chronology (2003-2018). Not directly connected to Marvel's 1970s-1990s continuity. Leads to: Conan Chronicles - Blood In His Wake.

title: Savage Sword Of Conan: The Original Marvel Years Omnibus Vol. 6 HC Jusko Cover
issues_collected: SAVAGE SWORD OF CONAN (1974) #73-84 and MARVEL COMICS SUPER SPECIAL #21
synopsis: The black-and-white Savage Sword magazine continues with issues #73-84, featuring mature-readers sword-and-sorcery tales by Roy Thomas, Bruce Jones, and others with stunning art from John Buscema, Val Mayerik, and more. These issues deliver some of the most atmospheric and violent Conan stories of the era, taking advantage of the magazine format's freedom from Comics Code restrictions. Marvel Comics Super Special #21 (1982) includes Conan the Barbarian movie adaptation material.
connection_notes: Continues from: Savage Sword Omnibus Vol. 5. Concurrent with Conan the Barbarian color series. The magazine format represents peak artistic achievement for Marvel's Conan.

title: Savage Sword Of Conan: The Original Marvel Years Omnibus Vol. 6 HC Panosian Cover
issues_collected: SAVAGE SWORD OF CONAN (1974) #73-84 and MARVEL COMICS SUPER SPECIAL #21
synopsis: The black-and-white Savage Sword magazine continues with issues #73-84, featuring mature-readers sword-and-sorcery tales by Roy Thomas, Bruce Jones, and others with stunning art from John Buscema, Val Mayerik, and more. These issues deliver some of the most atmospheric and violent Conan stories of the era, taking advantage of the magazine format's freedom from Comics Code restrictions. Marvel Comics Super Special #21 (1982) includes Conan the Barbarian movie adaptation material.
connection_notes: Continues from: Savage Sword Omnibus Vol. 5. Concurrent with Conan the Barbarian color series. The magazine format represents peak artistic achievement for Marvel's Conan.

title: Conan Chronicles Epic Collection: Blood In His Wake TPB
issues_collected: CONAN THE AVENGER #20-25 and CONAN THE SLAYER #1-12
synopsis: Continues Dark Horse's modern Conan chronology with Conan the Avenger #20-25 and the complete Conan the Slayer series (#1-12) from 2016-2017. Written by Cullen Bunn with art by Sergio Dávila and others, these stories follow Conan through his mercenary and wandering years. The material maintains Dark Horse's approach of telling chronological stories from different periods of Conan's life. Not Marvel continuity despite Epic Collection branding.
connection_notes: Continues from: Conan Chronicles - Shadows Over Kush. Part of Dark Horse's 2003-2018 Conan library, separate from Marvel's original 1970s-1990s continuity.

title: Conan The Barbarian Epic Collection: The Original Marvel Years — Of Once And Future Kings TPB
issues_collected: CONAN THE BARBARIAN (1970) #60-71, CONAN ANNUAL #2-3 and POWER RECORDS #31 — CONAN THE BARBARIAN: CRAWLER IN THE MISTS
synopsis: Roy Thomas and Barry Windsor-Smith's collaboration continues in Conan the Barbarian #60-71, marking Windsor-Smith's final regular issues on the title. This volume features the epic "Flame Winds" saga and introduces key supporting characters. Annuals #2-3 deliver extended adventures, while the Power Records audio drama adaptation adds a unique curiosity. These issues represent the end of Conan's definitive artistic era as John Buscema prepares to take over.
connection_notes: Continues from: Epic Collection - Queen of the Black Coast. Windsor-Smith's final issues before John Buscema becomes regular artist. Essential transition period in Marvel's Conan history.

title: Savage Sword Of Conan: The Original Marvel Years Omnibus Vol. 7 HC Larkin Cover
issues_collected: SAVAGE SWORD OF CONAN (1974) #88-101
synopsis: Savage Sword of Conan #88-101 delivers more mature-readers Hyborian adventures during the magazine's mid-1980s period. Roy Thomas, Don Kraar, and other writers contribute tales illustrated by Val Mayerik, John Buscema, and Gary Kwapisz. These issues maintain the magazine's reputation for sophisticated, violent storytelling while exploring both adaptations of Robert E. Howard tales and original Marvel stories. The magazine format continues to allow for more complex narratives than the Comics Code-approved color series.
connection_notes: Continues from: Savage Sword Omnibus Vol. 6. The Savage Sword magazine ran until 1995, making it one of Marvel's longest-running publications.

title: Savage Sword Of Conan: The Original Marvel Years Omnibus Vol. 7 HC Nowlan Cover
issues_collected: SAVAGE SWORD OF CONAN (1974) #88-101
synopsis: Savage Sword of Conan #88-101 delivers more mature-readers Hyborian adventures during the magazine's mid-1980s period. Roy Thomas, Don Kraar, and other writers contribute tales illustrated by Val Mayerik, John Buscema, and Gary Kwapisz. These issues maintain the magazine's reputation for sophisticated, violent storytelling while exploring both adaptations of Robert E. Howard tales and original Marvel stories. The magazine format continues to allow for more complex narratives than the Comics Code-approved color series.
connection_notes: Continues from: Savage Sword Omnibus Vol. 6. The Savage Sword magazine ran until 1995, making it one of Marvel's longest-running publications.

title: Conan The King: The Original Marvel Years Omnibus Vol. 1 HC Andrews Cover
issues_collected: KING CONAN (1980) #1-19
synopsis: King Conan #1-19 (1980) chronicles the barbarian's later years as ruler of Aquilonia, adapting Robert E. Howard's stories of an older, wiser Conan dealing with court intrigue, magic, and threats to his throne. Roy Thomas writes these tales with art primarily by John Buscema, exploring a rarely-seen phase of Conan's life. The series offers a different tone than the wandering barbarian stories, showing Conan as king, husband, and father facing challenges requiring wisdom as much as strength.
connection_notes: Set chronologically after most Conan the Barbarian stories. Essential for completionists wanting Conan's full life story. Concurrent with the ongoing Conan the Barbarian title.

title: Conan The King: The Original Marvel Years Omnibus Vol. 1 HC Buscema Cover
issues_collected: KING CONAN (1980) #1-19
synopsis: After two decades of adventure, Conan claims his throne as King of Aquilonia in this Roy Thomas-penned sequel series. King Conan #1-19 chronicles the warrior-king's struggles to hold his crown against political intrigue, supernatural threats, and old enemies returning from his barbarian past. John Buscema's artwork continues to define the visual identity of Marvel's Conan. This omnibus captures the transition from wandering adventurer to burdened monarch, exploring themes of responsibility and the price of power that make Conan's later years as compelling as his savage youth.
connection_notes: Follows chronologically after Conan the Barbarian's original run. Essential for understanding Conan's complete character arc from barbarian to king. Leads to King Conan/Conan the King issues collected in later volumes.

title: King Conan Chronicles Epic Collection: Phantoms And Phoenixes TPB
issues_collected: CONAN AND THE MIDNIGHT GOD #1-5, KING CONAN: THE SCARLET CITADEL #1-4, KING CONAN: THE PHOENIX ON THE SWORD #1-4, CONAN: THE PHANTOMS OF THE BLACK COAST #1-5 and material from AGE OF CONAN: HYBORIAN ADVENTURES.
synopsis: This modern Epic Collection assembles Dark Horse-era King Conan adventures from the 2000s-2010s, featuring Timothy Truman's adaptations of classic Robert E. Howard stories. The Phoenix on the Sword and The Scarlet Citadel adapt foundational Conan tales, while Midnight God and Phantoms of the Black Coast offer original stories set during Conan's reign. These are respectful adaptations with strong artwork, though they lack the historical significance of the original Marvel run. Completists seeking every King Conan story will appreciate these modern takes on Howard's source material.
connection_notes: These are Dark Horse publications from after Marvel's original run ended. Not essential to Marvel continuity but provides alternate interpretations of Howard's King Conan stories for devoted fans.

title: Conan The Barbarian Epic Collection: The Original Marvel Years - Vengeance In Asgalun TPB
issues_collected: CONAN THE BARBARIAN (1970) #72-88.
synopsis: Roy Thomas and John Buscema continue their legendary Conan run through issues #72-88, covering mid-period barbarian adventures. These issues showcase peak Thomas storytelling with intricate plots mixing Howard adaptations and original tales, including Conan's encounters with pirates, sorcerers, and ancient civilizations. While not as foundational as the first fifty issues, this era maintains the series' high quality and features some of Buscema's finest Conan artwork. Solid sword-and-sorcery adventures that demonstrate why the Thomas/Buscema partnership defined Marvel's Conan for nearly two decades.
connection_notes: Part of the continuous Thomas/Buscema run. Follows Conan the Barbarian Epic Collections covering earlier issues. Read after Omnibus Vols. 1-3 or their Epic Collection equivalents.

title: Conan The Barbarian: The Original Marvel Years Omnibus Vol. 8 HC Arthur Adams Cover
issues_collected: CONAN THE BARBARIAN (1970) #195-213 & ANNUAL (1973) #12 and THE OFFICIAL HANDBOOK OF THE CONAN UNIVERSE (1986) #1
synopsis: The Original Marvel Years conclude their eighth omnibus volume with Conan the Barbarian #195-213, featuring late-run adventures as Jim Owsley (Christopher Priest) takes over writing duties from Roy Thomas. These issues showcase a maturation of the series with increasingly sophisticated storytelling, though opinions vary on the post-Thomas direction. Annual #12 and the Official Handbook provide additional context. While not the definitive Conan era, these issues complete the story arc toward the series' eventual conclusion and represent an interesting evolutionary period for Marvel's barbarian.
connection_notes: Follows Omnibus Vol. 7. Represents the post-Roy Thomas era with new creative directions. For completists tracking the full original Marvel run through to its 1993 conclusion.

title: Conan The Barbarian: The Original Marvel Years Omnibus Vol. 8 HC Isherwood Cover
issues_collected: CONAN THE BARBARIAN (1970) #195-213 & ANNUAL (1973) #12 and THE OFFICIAL HANDBOOK OF THE CONAN UNIVERSE (1986) #1
synopsis: The Original Marvel Years conclude their eighth omnibus volume with Conan the Barbarian #195-213, featuring late-run adventures as Jim Owsley (Christopher Priest) takes over writing duties from Roy Thomas. These issues showcase a maturation of the series with increasingly sophisticated storytelling, though opinions vary on the post-Thomas direction. Annual #12 and the Official Handbook provide additional context. While not the definitive Conan era, these issues complete the story arc toward the series' eventual conclusion and represent an interesting evolutionary period for Marvel's barbarian.
connection_notes: Follows Omnibus Vol. 7. Represents the post-Roy Thomas era with new creative directions. For completists tracking the full original Marvel run through to its 1993 conclusion.

title: Savage Sword Of Conan: The Original Marvel Years Omnibus Vol. 8 HC Klein Cover
issues_collected: SAVAGE SWORD OF CONAN (1974) #102-116 and MARVEL COMICS SUPER SPECIAL #35
synopsis: Marvel's mature-readers Savage Sword magazine continues through issues #102-116, delivering unrestrained sword-and-sorcery tales free from Comics Code restrictions. This volume features work from Chuck Dixon, Don Kraar, and artists including John Buscema and Ernie Chan, offering bloodier, more adult Conan adventures alongside backup features exploring the Hyborian Age. Super Special #35 provides additional content. While the magazine format allowed for more graphic storytelling, this era lacks the cohesive vision of earlier Savage Sword issues, making it primarily of interest to hardcore Conan collectors.
connection_notes: Follows Savage Sword Omnibus Vol. 7. Represents mid-to-late era magazine stories running parallel to the color comic series. Can be read independently of the main Conan the Barbarian series.

title: Savage Sword Of Conan: The Original Marvel Years Omnibus Vol. 8 HC Sienkiewicz Cover
issues_collected: SAVAGE SWORD OF CONAN (1974) #102-116 and MARVEL COMICS SUPER SPECIAL #35
synopsis: Marvel's mature-readers Savage Sword magazine continues through issues #102-116, delivering unrestrained sword-and-sorcery tales free from Comics Code restrictions. This volume features work from Chuck Dixon, Don Kraar, and artists including John Buscema and Ernie Chan, offering bloodier, more adult Conan adventures alongside backup features exploring the Hyborian Age. Super Special #35 provides additional content. While the magazine format allowed for more graphic storytelling, this era lacks the cohesive vision of earlier Savage Sword issues, making it primarily of interest to hardcore Conan collectors.
connection_notes: Follows Savage Sword Omnibus Vol. 7. Represents mid-to-late era magazine stories running parallel to the color comic series. Can be read independently of the main Conan the Barbarian series.

title: Conan The Barbarian: The Original Marvel Years Omnibus Vol. 9 HC Higgins Cover
issues_collected: CONAN THE BARBARIAN (1970) #214-240 and WHAT IF? (1989) #16
synopsis: Conan the Barbarian #214-240 represents the series' final years before cancellation, with Roy Thomas returning periodically alongside other writers navigating the character through his last Marvel adventures. These issues continue building toward Conan's eventual kingship while maintaining sword-and-sorcery action, though the creative turnover shows. What If? #16 provides an alternate-history curiosity. This volume is essential for completists wanting the full original Marvel Conan saga but represents a series winding down rather than at its creative peak.
connection_notes: Follows Omnibus Vol. 8, continuing toward the series' 1993 conclusion at #275. Leads directly to Omnibus Vol. 10 which completes the original run.

title: Conan The Barbarian: The Original Marvel Years Omnibus Vol. 9 HC Lee Cover
issues_collected: CONAN THE BARBARIAN (1970) #214-240 and WHAT IF? (1989) #16
synopsis: Conan the Barbarian #214-240 represents the series' final years before cancellation, with Roy Thomas returning periodically alongside other writers navigating the character through his last Marvel adventures. These issues continue building toward Conan's eventual kingship while maintaining sword-and-sorcery action, though the creative turnover shows. What If? #16 provides an alternate-history curiosity. This volume is essential for completists wanting the full original Marvel Conan saga but represents a series winding down rather than at its creative peak.
connection_notes: Follows Omnibus Vol. 8, continuing toward the series' 1993 conclusion at #275. Leads directly to Omnibus Vol. 10 which completes the original run.

title: Conan The Barbarian: The Original Marvel Years Omnibus Vol. 10 HC Jim Lee Cover
issues_collected: CONAN THE BARBARIAN (1970) #241-275 and material from WHAT THE-?! #12
synopsis: The original Marvel Conan saga concludes with Conan the Barbarian #241-275, closing out the legendary 23-year run that began in 1970. Roy Thomas returns to guide the series to its finale, bringing Conan's journey full circle as he approaches his destiny as King of Aquilonia. These final issues mix nostalgia with closure, referencing decades of continuity while providing satisfying endings to long-running plot threads. The What The-?! #12 material offers humorous commentary. This omnibus is essential for anyone who's followed Conan's complete Marvel journey and wants to see how the epic concludes.
connection_notes: Completes the original Conan the Barbarian series that ran from 1970-1993. Follows Omnibus Vol. 9. After this, Conan's story continues chronologically in the King Conan series.

title: Conan The Barbarian: The Original Marvel Years Omnibus Vol. 10 HC Mcfarlane Cover
issues_collected: CONAN THE BARBARIAN (1970) #241-275 and material from WHAT THE-?! #12
synopsis: The final years of Marvel's original Conan license, collecting issues #241-275 from 1990-1993. This omnibus chronicles the twilight of Roy Thomas's legendary run as Conan transitions from barbarian to aging king, with artwork from Todd McFarlane, Mike Docherty, and others. These issues explore Conan's later adventures and the inevitability of his eventual decline, closing out Marvel's 23-year chapter of the character's saga. Features a rare What The-?! parody backup. While historically significant as the conclusion to Marvel's first Conan era, the quality varies considerably from the Thomas/Buscema glory days.
connection_notes: Concludes the run from Conan Omnibus Vol. 9. This marks the end of Marvel's original Conan publishing rights (which wouldn't return until 2019). Essential only for those completing the full Thomas run; casual readers should prioritize the Barry Windsor-Smith and John Buscema volumes.
